bibl.note: This is a letter dated October 3, 1838 from James King to his son Henry King. He tells his son to finish his business of selling meat, the prices he should expect, and tells him to make plans to come home.

opener.add: Refers to Genl King also to Wm R. King

div1.p: I was much pleased to here from you & friend, by your letter to Majr Woods

From what you rite, bacon must be a dull business, or you must be a bad sallesman, bacon is selling from 10 to 13 cts. hams from 12 1/2 to 15 cts in Nashville, I am thinking you are most two well satisfied their, and your friends treating you two well, for you to make much exertion; I wish you to sell out soon as practicable, but I do not think it advisable to sell for less than 14 or 15 cts. as it cant bearly be afforded for that, tho do the best you can, and come home shortly_ If you can sell your horse for a fair price do so. and take the staige_ I wrote to Mr Parrish a fiew days ago, and requested him to advise and instruct you about in any way he deam advisable_ I wish you to act morrally & preserve be high- minded & honourable, in so doing you will be welcomely received in any company majr Woods tell's me your friends ware glad to see you, and he was much pleased with thim, I feal much gratified at your being their, and flatter myself you will act prudent, especially as your cousin Parrish has left you and your young friend Bud to keep hous while they are from home,_ I would like for you to been in some better equipage while among your friends, tho your business did not so much require it_ I am inhopes the trip, and the mixing among different kind of pursons, the observations and experience, will add greatly to the cultivation and improvement of your mind
Tell Mr Parrish in all probility poark will be very high, I do't think it can be bought here for $5.- P. Thomas from the . West Districk. ware saying it coul'nt be bought for $8 in Brownsville, bacon is selling for 16 cts their.- Our corn crops are very short in consiquence of the drowth; Mr Woods says they have fine crops of corn in Alabama, and corn can be bought cheaper their than here_

Your mother joines me in respect to Mr Parrish cousin Ann & family, the genl. and family Wm R King and enquiring friends_ Tell cousin Ann I should be pleased to see her and hope I shall next spring, and hope to have Mr Parrish and her to spend the summer with us tell Ann to write to me_

LittleJames Moore has been very low with the fever, he is some better and a hope of his recovery your grandmother Butler had chils & fever but are clare of them and better_ Dunnaway has been very sick but is recovering_ My family are all well_ Majr Woods is quite well__ write to me imediately when you recd this if you are not ready to start home__
div1.closer: Your affectionate Father Ja M King To Henry A.J. King
